column4: Hi, I'm building a meta-dpkg and it has a bunch of dependencies that are also available in my repository, when I try installing <my-meta-package> I get a message about some of my dependencies stating "Depends: <other dependency> but it is not going to be installed"
I don't understand this message
Here is a pastebin of the output and my control file: http://pastebin.com/d1efb6512
And here is a pastebin of apt-cache policy <my-meta-package>: http://pastebin.com/d7e10ae2b
/ignore #ubuntu JOIN PART QUITS
you don't use apt to install your own packages. use dpkg
I do, I have my own apt repository for this
then it's not set up properly
that would seem to be the case, it works in all other cases, and my metapackages were working previously, so I don't understand the message
your new packages are NOT in your repo.end of story. either you put them in or you use dpkg, your choice
and next time come here DIRECTLY
fiddle util apt-cache policy shows a candidate from your repo
yes, my debian packages are in the relevant distro of my repository, I know this bwecause I created the new distro
look at my output, it does show it
it's not the meta package that has to be in ther. ALL, including dependencies have to be
all of my packages are in the repository
and the -gui policy output you showed me DID NOT have it as a candidate
apt-cache policy output for the -gui one then
http://pastebin.com/d775b6e79
and you still get http://pastebin.com/d3ff76a8b ?
yes
I actually don't believe you. ask someone else
